seat of a first-order administrative division
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Strategy for solid waste management in Baalback adopted

comment.narrative: Absence of integrated solid waste management in Caza of Baalbek

As per Master plan recommendations, 1) the secondary collection system equipments along with the COSV co-generator for the proper implementation of the biogas plant are procured, and 2) Baalbeck maintenance workshop is rehabilitated.

-Procurement of the secondary collection system (refuse collection vehicles): The 3 Isuzu pick up trucks with rear tipper body along with the 4 Renault D18 are ready to be delivered by the supplier and are only pending the processing of the necessary paper work by the municipality for registration, the 5 Renault D13 will follow shortly; -The procurement process for the rehabilitation works at the Baalbek maintenance workshop is finalised, pending the signature of the winning bidder; -The procurement of the co-generator needed for the proper operation of the COSV biogas facilities is underway; -The design of the temporary closure of the Kayal dumpsite is being finalized and then the tender documents shall be prepared for the bidding firms to implement the works.

- The Municipality of Baalbek is adequately equipped to manage solid waste: maintenance workshop is rehabilitated; the secondary collection system is upgraded through acquiring and refurbishing a number of trucks and other solid waste fleet; the bio-energy co-generators are procured for the successful operation of the biogas production plant; -The Kayal dumpsite is cleaned and temporarily closed as a first step towards its full rehabilitation.

'-The fleet of waste collection trucks was procured and handed over to the Baalbek municipality; - Baalbek maintenance workshop was rehabilitated and equipped; -The rehabilitation of the Kayal dumpsites could not be completed awaiting the construction of a proper sanitary landfill; -The bid to procure the co-generator was cancelled subsequent to the incident of setting the sorting/composting facilities on fire the night of 24/25 Sep 2016 by an unknown group; -The project was extended until 31 December 2016 awaiting the final decision on the remaining activities.

- Project work-plan and activities are revised in consultation with project partners - Supply the municipality of Baalbek with the needed co-generators for the proper operation of the biogas production facilities - Completion of Kayal dumpsite rehabilitation or alternative activity according to revised workplan

'The project will proceed with the procurement of the biogas cogenerators needed for the proper operation of theBaalbek biogas production facilities. Consultation with main partners is maintained in order to plan remaining implementation of the project.

comment.narrative: - SMEs have limited access to credits in under-served regions of Lebanon - SMEs have limited access to business support in under-served regions of Lebanon - Local development initiatives scattered and implemented with limited impact
Increase job creation in under-served regions of Lebanon Support community development initiatives in under-served regions of Lebanon
Increase job creation in under-served regions of Lebanon Support community development initiatives in under-served regions of Lebanon

The ESFD and the BDS team have identified with the launch of both Financing Agreements (LEB MED) the under-served regions as well as the potential end borrowers. During Q1 2017, around 66 credit applications for projects’ financing were submitted by the BDS officers to ESFD partner banks.
During Q1 2017, 45 projects directed through BDS officers were financed, accounting for almost 31% of total projects financed by the 6 partner banks.
During Q1 2017, a total of 144 projects (loans equaling LBP 3.7 Billion) were financed in the targeted regions to increase the growth and prosperity for small and medium enterprises in the under-served regions of Lebanon. These projects are expected to create 131 jobs.
The ESFD is continuing the process of projects identification with special emphasis on communities hosting Syrian Refugees. During the reporting period, the ESFD provided technical assistance to several communities to prepare participatory needs assessment and hence come up with identification priority interventions. These communities included the urban area of Ras El Dekwaneh, and the Union of Municipalities of Eastern Zahle.
The ESFD is still implementing infrastructure projects in communities hosting Syrian Refugees. Out of 11 water, waste water and solid waste projects, 8 potable water projects were completed in Qobbeh, Kfartoun, Qonia, Sahleh, and Mhamara in the North, and Saadnayel and Sawiri in the Bekaa in addition to one waste water project in Ghazza Bekaa. During the next quarter, the ESFD will finalize the implementation of the remaining potable water project in Wadi Khaled in Akkar amounting to EUR 2 million, the solid waste management facility in Bar Elias amounting to EUR 4.5 million and will continue the implementation of the waste water project in Hermel amounting to EUR 3.2 million.
During the reporting period, the ESFD launched the tendering process for 5 agricultural infrastructure projects amounting to around EUR 3 million and an extension

provider-org.narrative: OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMA
OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMA
OFFICE OF THE HIGH COMMISSIONER FOR HUMA

description.narrative: - Internship program established - Training provided to Parliamentary Administration employees - Support provided to Parliament to address reform issues with key stakeholders/participatory approach - Inter-parliamentary agreements reached - Accountability role of parliamentarians exercised and issues raised - Information disclosed - Tracking system for legislative process developed - Media Campaign to promote Human Rights Action Plan developed - Support provided to the Human Right Parliamentary Committee - National Human Rights Action Plan finalized and adopted

comment.narrative: Need to modernize the current organizational and administrative structure of the parliament, and to develop capacities of and provide support to the administration to address critical reform issues Need for further follow-up on Parliamentary Interrogations, and enhancing the understanding of government accountability to the Parliament Need to implement and follow-up on the National Human Rights Action Plan and mainstreaming Human Rights in Parliamentary work.

1. Organizing at least 2 training sessions for CSOs on women quota with the participation of relevant committees. 2. Organizing an event on the International Human Rights Day to launch the final NHRIP 3. Enrolling at least 5 new interns through the Lebanese Parliamentary Internship Program (LPIP) 4. Partnerships developed with Parliamentary Committees

1. Co-organized a national conference on special temporary measures for women participation in elections, with CSOs, women candidates, and representatives of major political blocks (Member of Parliaments) . Participated in the sessions of the Administration and Justice Parliamentary Committee to suggest the introduction of a 30% women quota to the electoral law (as a starting point). Received commitment from a number of Members of Parliament incl. the Speaker of Parliament on the adoption of the quota. Published a QA guide on the women quota and a study on the role of women in political parties. 2. Launched (in partnership with the Arab NGO Network for Development) the 2015 Universal Periodic Review on Human Rights report. Awareness was raised among CSOs, Members of Parliament, and experts, with recommendations and mechanisms to implement the recommendations. A task force was accordingly established. 3. 9 new interns joined the LPIP and worked with committees, directorates, and parliamentary administration. 4. Active partnerships in the form of support (logistical and advisory) provided to the Administration and Justice, Human Rights, Youth, and Woman and Child Parliamentary Committees.

- At least 3 research studies (focusing on national priority areas) published and disseminated - Increasing the number of enrolled interns to accept at least 10 students - Organizing at least one public hearing session on regional development related to Syrian refugees - Mobilize resources to develop and realize the National Human Rights Implementation Plan

• Five public hearing sessions on regional development organized for the provinces of Akkar, Bekaa, North, South and Mount Lebanon with summary reports drafted. • One workshop to launch the SDGs toolkit with summary report drafted. • Lebanese Parliamentary Internship programme expanded and number of enrolled interns increased to accepting a minimum of 30 graduates. • A workshop on the importance of women’s participation in conflict resolution and negotiation and developing an electoral law, organized. • A workshop on the importance of adopting a gender quota in the electoral law or in the Lebanese Constitution, organized.

Support to enhance inclusive participation in public policy and in the legislative process provided Legal Framework for the upcoming Parliamentary Elections Lobbying for a women quota A unified paper of the relevant demands was developed and discussed with the National Commission for Lebanese Women. The paper was adopted by 150 organizations and was submitted to the Prime Minister and the Minister of State for Women Affairs. The structure of the coalition was planned and accordingly, a media committee, a legal committee, a lobbying and advocacy committee were created and a general coordinator to the coalition was appointed. A press conference was organized to launch the unified demand paper developed by the project, in addition to a series of questions and answers relevant to the objectives of the coalition. Both documents were distributed to the members of the coalition and the press. A draft law proposal was developed in order to incorporate the concept of gender to the electoral law, the draft was submitted to the Minister The project participated in a televised interview for “Why the Law” program on Tele Liban. The interview discussed the definition of the women quota concept and the importance of it being included in the electoral law under study Lobbying to prevent Child Marriage The project initiated and supported the establishment of a “Child Protection Coalition” Upon the request of the project, the Woman and Child parliamentary committee organized a meeting to denounce the draft law proposal “organizing child marriage” under study at Parliament. This had a positive impact on MPs who chaned the draft law's name and asked for a workshop on that matter. The project organized a workshop entitled ‘Preventing Child Marriage’ in the framework of a series of workshops to achieve the 5th Sustainable Development Goal. The workshop successfully led to the adoption of the “Child Protection Coalition” draft law proposal on raising the age for marriage to 18 years by

Improvement in key fiscal indicators Reports (statistics) on public services, social programs and subsides, and beneficiaries published MTEF updates completed Deviation of publications calendar controlled client/user satisfaction and action (survey) provided The publication of the debt management strategy The extent of deviation from the financing target FX and LL bond issuance successfully undertaken Number of tax conventions and investment agreements signed and results Proportion of legal reviews and advisory notes accepted/acted upon Report on reform implementation TA implementation ratio against plan TA evaluation and beneficiaries survey Budget support disbursed Grants and loans mobilized as forecasted Sector financing plans approved Aid effectiveness measures adopted Higher compliance rate Improved services Increased revenues collection Reduction in clearance time Reduction on clearance cost Stabilization of effective tariff rate Increase in voluntary compliance Inter-governmental collaboration Compliance with international obligations

comment.narrative: The fiscal situation at the end of 2010 shows gaps in the macro-fiscal policy measures, gauged by the main fiscal indicators and by public services, social programs, subsidies, and beneficiaries as in 2010. The 2010 MTEF. The publications programme as achieved in 2010. 2010 Medium-term debt management strategy (internal dissemination). The 2010 Financing plan. The results of the 64 tax agreements and 49 investment agreements reached in 2010 and on the legal reviews and advisory notes completed in 2010. Building on the reform programmes implemented in the previous years and responding to the gaps that remain to be filled: The Paris III MoF reform programme implementation as of end 2010. TA data base and neeeds as of end 2010. Annual aid mobilization forecast as achieved end 2010. Project-based financing situation as of end 2010. Progress of tax reform programme implementation as of end 2010 Weaknesses in the current facilitations and compliance as follows: Clearance of cargo: Average 5 days or above Documentation:Average 10 docs per transaction Compliant self assessment: Red lane 30 percent Satisfaction level of trade community: Medium to Low Percent added revenue due to Enforcement: Less than 2 percent Percent Non-compliant operations: Estimated 10-15 percent

1. Incentive proposals for sustainable energy submitted 2. Growth model for MoF implemented 3. Model developed to study the impact of oil discoveries on fiscal and debt 4. Second phase of transfer to administration completed 5. Thematic report series developed and reports widely disseminated 6. Sustainable energy/environment portfolio institutionalized 7. Requests for legal review and advice satisfactorily met/acted upon 8. Aid mobilization annual target achieved 9. Large Taxpayers Office merger procedures implemented 10. Performance Management System implemented 11. Operational Call Centre ensured 12. E-services business rules provided 13. Awareness and communication campaigns launched 15. New GIS solution implemented

1. Developed a medium term macro-fiscal framework for 2015 onwards. 2. Managed the highest Eurobond transaction ever accomplished amounting to 2.8 BN US Dollars. 3. Created a five-year debt model to assess financial and debt risks. 4. Provided suggestions to the amendment of the money laundering law passed by Parliament (ref. Official Gazette no. 48). 5. Introduced at least 10 new forms to facilitate tax procedures and services. Established new automated modules for the Tax administration. Launched an e-services platform to speed up processes and transactions for citizens. Established a one stop shop for 128 transactions. Call center strategy developed. 6. Modernization of the Land Registry and Cadastre administration supported by automation based on international best practices and training of all staff on new systems. Opening of new regional centers in South Lebanon to decentralize processes.

- Support provided so as annual fiscal and debt targets met - Impact of the Syrian conflict on the revenues and expenditures, including EDL and interest payments thoroughly studied, and socio-economic and fiscal policies in light of the burden imposed by the Syrian conflict reviewed and assessed - Publications calendar following transfer of regular publications to administration timely and successfully implemented - Incentive proposals for sustainable energy submitted - Investment agreements file being transferred gradually to the administration - Requests for legal review and advice satisfactorily met/acted upon - Fiscal reform programme implementation reported on - IFIs, EIB relationship managed and portfolio developed - MoF TA mobilized as planned - Large Taxpayers Office merger implemented - The administrative and operational capacity of the Tax Administration modernized (STR3 implemented) - E-services business rules provided for at least 3 procedures and awareness campaign implemented - Operations at the Free Zone is 5 percent faster and control improved by 10 percent - Operation in terms of Transit is at least 10 percent faster and the control function improved of 15% - Visas and permits delivery is 10 percent faster

Energy - policy, planning and administration
Action plans, standards, regulator frameworks and policy options elaborated.

comment.narrative: Absence of adequate Quality, Health, Safety and Environment (QHSE) regulatory framework for the oil and gas industry and unclear policies related to uses of natural gas in the transport sector

-In presense of the main stakeholders, a consultation workshop for the preparation of a National Oil Spill Contingency Plan to present the main findings of the “Gap Analysis and Challenges Report” was conducted in February. The report was finalized and submitted. Constant coordination with Project Stakeholders from the main Ministries to discuss their respective proposed roles in the NOSCP is undergoing. - The ToRs for the procurement of consultancy service to develop HSE Framework for the Oil and Gas Sector in Lebanon was finalized. -Consultancy services for the preparation of CBAs for the use of natural gas and low carbon fuels in the transport and energy sector are undergoing. An infrastructure analysis report was submitted for both consultancies and the work on the CBA reports has started. - A legal Consultant was hired under Component II to conduct a legislative framework study

-The preparation of the HSE framework in the Oil Gas sector in Lebanon is ongoing. Several Consultation workshops with Norwegian experts from the Norwegian Environment Agency (NEA) and Petroleum Safety Authority (PSA) were held to discuss a most suitable HSE governance option for Lebanon, - The ToRs for the procurement of IC consultancy services to prepare the NOSCP SOPs were finalized. The Request for Proposal (RFP) was posted online on UNDP website in May for a period of 3 weeks. The recruitment process is ongoing, -The ToRs for the procurement of IC consultancy services to develop a Pilot Study for the use of Natural Gas in the Energy sector in Lebanon were finalized. The Request for Proposal (RFP) was posted online on UNDP website in May for a period of 1 month. The recruitment process is ongoing, -The legislative framework study for the transport and energy sectors is being prepared. An additional task was included in the TOR to prepare a research on the legal requirements needed to establish a unit for implementing projects related to the use of alternative fuels in the energy transport sectors, -An awareness event entitled "Towards Sustainable Transportation in Developing Countries" was held on April 22nd by the MoEW and UNDP SODEL and in collaboration with the Lebanese American university (LAU) to present the results of the “CBA for the Use of Natural Gas and Low Carbon Fuels in the Transport Sector” that was conducted under the SODEL Project last year.

comment.narrative: Political debate on electoral reform on-going Limited technical capacity for advising on reform initiatives Inadequate technical framework for results process Limited technical capacity for improving results framework Need to ensure accurate and reliable results process Limited experience and capacity for official voter information No current strategy for official role on voter information and media; increasing political role for social media Limited use and awareness of online voter register Broad public knowledge of importance of elections but limited knowledge of electoral issues Emerging role and expectation for official websites and voter information on citizens’ rights Limited official resources for meeting media interest Possible political consensus on measures for vote secrecy No current capacity for ballot production and limited technical knowledge on options for counting and absentee voting No strategic capacity for training of officials in place All polling officials require updated training, especially if new electoral procedures to be adopted Limited technical capacity and resources for operational planning and data-management Limited opportunities for Persons With Disabilities (PWD) to access electoral process Debate for future reform of legislative and administrative framework for elections is likely to intensify Donors of electoral assistance will seek quality assurance. Next elections will take place in 2016 and 2017 SCEC has no current functional capacity. SCEC members and staff will be new with limited elections experience Regulatory framework for campaign supervision identified as inadequate No strategy or capacity for stakeholder outreach in place Limited capacity for observer accreditation in place Significant interest from observer/media expected Debate for future strengthening of campaign supervision is expected to take place Donors of electoral assistance will seek quality assurance No baseline data or coordina

1. Improved candidate registration system 2. Improved results management system 3. Enhanced electoral dispute resolution processes 4. Outreach material provided 5. Increased awareness on Temporary Special Measures for women participation

1. CRRM software to modernize candidate registration and results management finalized, tested, and provided to the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities. System preliminary adopted by the Directorate General for Personal Status. 2. Developed partnership with the constitutional council, providing it with technical support to be able to address electoral disputes. Information capacity of the council enhanced with a website and the publication of 2 legal references (guidebook and compilation of decisions). The project received a recognition award for its contributions. 3. Capacities on elections operations strengthened through the publication of an electoral atlas for each electoral district with elections related data and improved storage capacity and management of electoral material through the establishment of an automated system. 4. Increased awareness on women participation provided with advisory support to parliamentary committees, with the provision of information and alternatives and facts, and co-organization of a national conference to discuss Temporary Special measures.

• Support the MoIM, SCEC, Constitutional and State Councils in the planning, organization and conduct of the municipal elections in its different stages. • Support the process of candidates registration for municipal elections and parliamentary bi-elections through the implementation of a modern candidate registration software (pilot) conducted in parallel with the current system. • Support in the design and conduct of trainings for the candidate registration officials at 26 'Qaem maqams'. • Technical support to the 26 'Qaem maqams' during the candidate registration period • Support in the establishment of the MoIM media center and hotline, and support for the maintenance and development of the website • Regular trainings and briefings for media and observers on municipal elections (depending on pre-elections period length) • Support the MoIM and Civil Society Organizations in the organization and conduct of cascade trainings for polling officials, accreditation unit, media and observers, hotline operators, CSO representatives, and women organizations • Technical support to the MoIM Operation Room during the electoral period. • Organization and conduct of meetings between MoIM and persons with disabilities NGOs in order to identify concrete measures to increase accessibility to the polling locations. • Conducting at least 3 full awareness campaigns (media and direct targeting) aiming at voter education, voter registration, and elections day requirements. • Conducting a national workshop on strengthening the participation of women in municipal elections as voters, candidates and polling officials. • Development of a guide for municipal elections focused on candidacy procedure (Arabic and English) aimed to to provide relevant information to women interested to run as candidates. • Ensure proper evaluation of programs and highlighting of lessons learned after the completion of the municipal elections with a focus on women participation; Post-electoral evaluation

LEAP launched the 2017 public awareness campaign on voter registration update, which ran from 10 February to 10 March. LEAP launched and operated the Voter Registration hotline center during the voter registration update period. LEAP updated the official MOIM website with new elections decisions and announcements, the 2009 elections archive and other relevant electoral information. LEAP updated the voter registration querying system and accreditation tool in preparation of the parliamentary elections. LEAP launched the English version of the Constitutional Council website. LEAP organized a two days BRIDGE training course on Gender and Elections aiming to increase knowledge and awareness of the scope of Temporary Special Measures, and building capacity to advocate for affirmative actions and Temporary Special Measures LEAP in partnership with Women in Front organized eight training sessions in different Lebanese governorate aiming to encourage women to participate in the political life as candidates and run for the upcoming parliamentary elections. LEAP produced a guide and short animated movie on “the Participation of Lebanese Women in Political Life/ Quota TSMs”. LEAP launched the Gender Quota toolkit “the Participation of Lebanese Women in Political Life/ Quota TSMs” on the occasion of Women’s International Day at UNDP premises in Beirut.

Saida dumpsite totally rehabilitated and environmental impacts mitigated.

comment.narrative: Current dumpsite presents high risk and environmental hazard, and absence of baseline data

-The rehabilitated dumpsite is converted into two sections: 1) a Public Park (area 33,500 sqm) including 10,452 trees and plants and irrigation system open to citizens; and b) a sanitary engineered landfill becomes a green hill 65,000 sqm. All infrastructure (fences, access road, drainage, guard house/equipped room) is completed; gas and leachate are monitored.

-Trainings for the Project Team Local Stakeholders to Ensure Proper Project Performance are undertaken; -The dumpsite is converted into: 1) a Public Park (area 33,500 sqm) including 10,452 trees and plants and irrigation system open to citizens; and b) an engineered sanitary landfill becomes a green hill 65,000 sqm. All infrastructure (fences, access road, drainage, guard house/equipped room) is completed; gas and leachate are monitored.

description.narrative: Enhacing Capacity for Social Development
Enhacing Capacity for Social Development
independent political entity

- Number of NSDS launched and adopted by MoSA - Elaboration and adaptation of National Social Development Plan - Issuance of a contractual modality with clear standards between MoSA and NGOs. - Number of NGOs classified according to an accreditation system - Number of welfare institutions classified according to an accreditation system. - Percentage of low qualified contacted NGO’s welfare institutions trained. - Percentage of MoSA staff trained. - Establishment of an active solid networking between MOSA, NGOs and other donors.

comment.narrative: - Lack of a national social development strategy to be adopted by ministers, NGOs, local authorities for implementing local initiatives and promoting sustainable development. - Lack of training tools and techniques to build the capacities of MoSA staff. - Absence of clear standards for selecting qualified NGOs for contractual cooperation with MoSA. - Lack of a solid networking mechanism to formulate the cooperation between MoSA and NGOs, among NGOs themselves and between NGOs and other donors. - Lack of a coherant platform among MoSA, NGOs and other donors for sharing data and and information available on services and beneficiaries in an attempt to avoid duplication and to ensure a sound allocation of resources.
The National Social Development Strategy is launched and adopted by MoSA An action plan is elaborated New criteria contractual procedure are established
Re-launch the National Social Development Strategy of Lebanon

In the context improving the capacity of MoSA, several initiatives were launched and followed up during Q1, 2017: 1) A proposal for expanding ECSD (in time and scope): A new project concept was elaborated towards a future expansion of the scope of the “Enhancing Capacity for Social Development“ Project. The proposal builds on the emerging priorities in the Ministry in terms of the need for improving institutional and human capacity, and the eminent need for developing a strategic framework to guide MoSA’s activities over the medium term. A result framework was prepared along with the needed funding. 2) Final review of the policy papers prepared under ESCD: Further to the request of the Director General, the nine policy papers were subject to a thorough review towards finalizing the papers and taking the necessary actions regarding the potential use of these papers in guiding MoSA’s preparation of own strategy. 3) Preparatory steps for Strategy Development (MOSA): As a groundwork for launching MoSA’s strategy preparation, two essential documents were prepared: i) A roadmap for strategy preparation detailing the different phases of the process including data gathering, workshops and drafting, and ii) an administrative memo to form the working group in MoSA, who will be responsible for the strategy preparation, from the Ministry’s side, along with the detailed mandate of this working group. 4) Assessment of the training function in the Ministry of Social Affairs: A quick and thorough assessment of the training function was completed and shared with the administration. The assessment covered the Training Department in the Ministry along with to the Social Training Centre. The assessment resulted in identifying the main problems to be tackled in future interventions to improve the training function in the Ministry.

comment.narrative: -0 reduction of CO2 emissions -Regulations for feed-in tariffs and net metering under consideration -No adequate market monitoring and quality control mechanisms in place

-Inception Workshop held on 29 January 2015 with the participation of national counterparts and main stakeholders. -NEEREA Financial study is completed and recommendations have been presented. An action plan ideveloped to address the relevant recommendations. -NEEREA Application Tutorial Workshop for Renewable Energy Projects Workshop held during Beirut Energy Forum (BEF). -Consultants to conduct the Renewable Energy Grid Code study commenced work. -The Expression of Interest for companies is completed; 18 companies out of 31 qualified to work with DREG; -Renewable Energy Market Monitoring Survey is finalized and to be launched in parallel with the Beneficiary Application Form. -NEEREA Applications Process QA + DREG Workshop for Lebanese commercial banks held at Banque du Liban (BdL) on 4 December 2015. -Beneficiary Application Form for DREG's demonstration projects is launched so that shortlisted RE companies and potential beneficiaries can apply, in partnership, to DREG for support.

-Implementation of at least 1.75 MW of decentralized renewable energy projects is initiated with the support of a technical firm; -A number of studies is completed in partnership with other projects and published (Renewable Energy Interconnection Grid Code; Derisking Renewable Energy Investment Study; Net-metering Study) -A number of capacity building workshops are conducted (Earthing and Lightning Protection of PV Systems, Embedding of PV technologies in building design and construction, Net-metering) and related guidelines are issued; -PV Survey is undertaken and Market Monitoring Reporting is established; -Quality Control of PV Installations is introduced in vocational schools through updating the curriculum and personnel training.

-Evaluation of 13 beneficiary application forms for the demonstration projects is completed and 9 beneficiaries/facilities were selected totalling a capacity of 2.6 MWp. -Site visits for the 9 selected facilities are completed and 6 design reviews are finalised with 3 more to go. -6 MOUs have been signed with the beneficiaries applying for the NEEREA loan before implementation can begin. -Grid Code Data Assessment and Guidelines Reports completed and transferred to MoEW for review and recommendation. -Lebanon's first PV Status Report has been launched for 2015: total installed capacity for Solar PV is 10 MWp worth $31M. -The mission to Beirut for the Derisking Renewable Energy Investment Study is completed and the first draft report is currently under review. -Earthing and Lightning Protection for PV Systems Workshop conducted with attendees from various private sector companies and EDL. The purpose of it was to present the proper guidelines to be used for grounding and protecting Solar PV systems from lightning and faults. -Additional PV quality standards have been approved and adopted in collaboration with LIBNOR/MoI. -Translation from English to French of the PV course which will be embedded in the vocational schools' Electrotechnical curriculum is completed. Work is underway to have it adopted in the curricu

description.narrative: Increased supply/storage of water to host communities in Wadi Khaled

comment.narrative: Limited supply and storage capacity available resulting in non-continuous supply of water
The construction of transmission and distribution water networks for Hnaider, Qarha Knaise villages in Wadi Khaled, North Lebanon is 80 percent completed.

-Approximately $2.2 million has already been allocated to the construction of the primary and secondary water network in four villages in Wadi Khaled (Knaisee, Hnaider, Qarha and Al Majdal). All technical designs were completed in coordination with the hosting municipalities; concerning the implementation progress, the transmission distribution lines as well as the house connections for Knaisse, Quarha and Hnaider were constructed, tested and ready to be handed over to the Water Establishment. Also all reservoirs were rehabilitated, and the water pump dedicated to deliver the water to the whole reservoirs is replaced. -Regarding Al Majdal, 70% of the main distribution line is implemented. -The works covered by the SDC funds (included above) are 100% finalised; a field visit was undertaken with the Donor. The final report was submitted to the Donor. -The works covered by KFW fund are 80% finalised. the remaining works is planned to be completed by end of April 2016. -Additional resources from KFW were mobilised and will be implemented in 2016-2017; -Additional resources were mobilised from USBPRM to implement wastewater treatment initiatives; to be completed in 2016.

'- Completion of construction of the Waste Water Collection Network and Septic Tank in Knaisse and Hnaider Villages in Wadi Khaled, North Lebanon, under the United States Government (USBPRM) funds. - Under the German funds (KFW) phase II, the construction of Concrete Irrigation Canals and Networks in Machha- Akkar is completed and in the handing over process, while other irrigation networks projects are still under implementation in Tal Abbas and Tal Hayat in Akkar and Kfarnabrakh in Mount Lebanon. As for the project in Quobayat, Akkar, the contract has been awarded and the mobilization will start soon. - Under the German funds (KfW) phase III, the irrigation networks projects in Al Qaa and qab Elias have been awarded and are in the mobilization phase. As for the village of Machghara, it is still in the evaluation process. Identification of further Bekaa villages to implement irrigation networks is ongoing.
- Assessment of the Conditions of the Deir Dloum Canal, Proposing Protection Measures and submitting design has been completed. - Working to allocate new funds for new regions especially in Mount Lebanon. - Follow-up on the date and details of hand over and inaugurations with the MoEW - A pre-qualification (FOI) to screen contractorsis being prepared and will be launched soon

comment.narrative: 1) Rising tensions in schools hosting Syrian refugees 2) Absence of a collective memory of the civil war 3) High level of violence in Lebanese public and private schools 4) Absence of context-specific peace education content in the current high school curricula (including civics/history/geography education 5) Limited opportunities within the formal education sector to build a collective memory 6) Absence of new and modern ways of teaching history and sensitive topics 7) Need to implement master training for teacher trainers in use of Peace Building Toolbox 8) Limited initiatives involving young generation in oral history and the need to work on historical narrative 9)Lack of impartial and multifaceted reporting on issues affecting social cohesion in Lebanon and with communities hosting Syrian refugees in particular 10)The Journalists’ Pact for Strengthening Civil Peace signed but not yet implemented 11)Limited media monitoring on the type of and effects of reporting 12)Poor or biased coverage of strategic issues regarding the implementation of past agreements 13)Lack of channels for conveying positive messages through media 14) Absence of sustained peace building and dialogue mechanisms to mitigate the risks of potential violence at the local level 15) Limited awareness of the role that local actors such as municipalities and mukhtars can play in conflict prevention and mitigation. 16) Worsening tension between the Lebanese host communities and the Syrian refugees 17) Lack of a joint road map and a national strategy for truth and reconciliation 18) Limited field research on the perception of the causes, lived experience, and impact of the civil war in Lebanon, 19) Lack of consultation and coordination with state, non-state and other various segments of the Lebanese society on reconciliation 20) Absence awareness among the population about truth, reconciliation and dealing with the past through media 21) Absence of active - Restructuring plans developed - Coordination initiatives enhanced -Launch specific social and economic projects including support to entrepreneurs - E-government platform and tools developed - Regular ICT Ministerial Committee meetings held at least quarterly - Number of developed ICT policies and regulations - Internal and external communication strategies developed and tested - Number of publications drafted and disseminated - Number of infrastructural projects developed and implemented

comment.narrative: Need for more thorough coordination among institutions on policies The national e-strategy plan is developed but needs implementation and follow-up Successful implementation of infrastructural projects, that need to be enhanced and further elaborated

1. Reform of the statistical system in Lebanon 2. Improving the business environment in Lebanon 3. National Poverty Targeting Program supported 4. Cultural and Religious Tourism plan resumed 5. e-strategy plan followed-up

1. Amendments suggested to reform the central administration of statistics, maintaining its independence from political interventions and strengthening its authority. 2. Supported the central bank in developing a circular to settle debt resolution cases of companies, a draft law on preferred shares submitted to parliament. 3. Funds were secured to provide e-card voucher for 5,027 deprived households. More funds were mobilized to increase target in 2016 (aiming at 27,000 households). 4. Resumed the Cultural and Religious Tourism project. Discussions launched with municipalities and religious groups. 5. Coordinating e-strategy/ICT work with ministries to generate new ICT policies, all finalized and submitted to the Council of Ministers. Finalize equipment of 5 regional operations rooms on disaster risk management. Kick started phase 1 of the automation process of the Office of the Presidency of the Council of Ministers.

- Coordinate among Key Ministries and institutions including Ministries of Finance, Economy and Trade, Social Affairs, and IDAL, to propose relevant public policy reform plans and develop a medium-term development strategy - Provide Technical Support to the Central Administration of Statistics for a reform program for the statistical system and an implementation plan - Support in developing social development policies and coordinate the implementation of the Regional Development Strategy - Coordinate with OMSAR for developing e-government electronic tools and services and implementing them in at least 4 pilot projects - Coordinate with key ministries to Re-launch the meetings of the ICT Ministerial Committee - Coordinate with key ministries to propose at least 4 ICT/e-Governance procedures and policies - Support to Updating the ICT Watch website - Provide guidelines and technical support to the OPCM and other government agencies on all infrastructure projects

Enhancing Road Safety in coordination with the Municipality of Beirut and other municipalities around Beirut to ease up traffic and provide more public parking Burj Hamoud landfill operations are in progress for removing and treating the existing hill-like dump in parallel with the completion of additional cells to receive in bails the sorted solid waste, in addition to the Costa Brava Landfill which will receive similar Bails until June of 2017 Involving more municipalities and EU supported programs through OMSAR (more funds available from EU sources, but this needs the swift action of the municipalities to submit their applications to attain such funds or donations in kind), the Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Interior and Municipalities for the creation of a working decentralized system for the municipal solid waste cleaning, collection, sorting, recycling, composting, proper land filling within the geographical areas of each municipality Updating Automating Public Employees Database Designating the Vacancies in each Level Area of Service, and Prioritizing the Posts to be filled. Selecting Potential Suitable Candidates from a Nominations’ Database for Government Posts. Organizing Appraisal Meetings with the Selected Candidates, conducted by a Committee assigned by the Prime Minister. Preparing Appraisal Reports for the Prime Minister, and a Final Nominations Report by potential Post-to-be-filled. Collection of information related to the needs and problems of the municipalities to establish coordination between the concerned parties Coordinate, with the support the Economic Advisors of the PM, on various SDGs issues, particularly for background preparations to launch the Governmental National Plan to implement the UN SDGs. Roundtables were organized with public and private sector to take stock of challenges in the ecosystem and compile a list of reforms the government can implement.
